pageProps.contentHtml:
change of variables, conformal mappings

Let QQQ be the closed unit square in the complex plane C\CC and let RRR be the closed rectangle in C\CC with vertices {0,2,i,2+i}\set{0, 2, i, 2+i}{0,2,i,2+i}. Prove that there does not exist a surjective homeomorphism f ⁣:Q→R\func{f}{Q}{R}f:Q→R that is conformal on the interior QoQ^\itrQo and that maps corners to corners.
Solution.

Suppose f ⁣:Q→R\func{f}{Q}{R}f:Q→R is such a mapping. Parametrize ∂Q\partial{Q}∂Q counter-clockwise by γ\gammaγ. Since fff is continuous and injective, this means that f∘γf \circ \gammaf∘γ is a simple closed curve. Suppose (f∘γ)∩Ro≠∅\p{f \circ \gamma} \cap R^{\itr} \neq \emptyset(f∘γ)∩Ro=∅. Then by the Jordan curve theorem, this implies the existence of w1w_1w1​ in the interior region of f∘γf \circ \gammaf∘γ and w2w_2w2​ in the exterior region. But the interior and exterior regions are disconnected, which implies that f(Qo)f\p{Q^{\itr}}f(Qo) is disconnected, which is impossible as it is the continuous image of a connected set. Thus, f∘γ⊆∂Rf \circ \gamma \subseteq \partial{R}f∘γ⊆∂R, and because fff maps corners to corners in an injective way, it follows that f∘γ=∂Rf \circ \gamma = \partial{R}f∘γ=∂R.

Since fff is injective, it traverses the vertices of RRR in a clockwise or counter-clockwise way. By reversing γ\gammaγ if necessary, we may assume that f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0, f(1)=2f\p{1} = 2f(1)=2, f(1+i)=2+if\p{1 + i} = 2 + if(1+i)=2+i, and f(i)=if\p{i} = if(i)=i. For y∈[0,1]y \in \br{0, 1}y∈[0,1] consider the segment Cy=[iy,1+iy]C_y = \br{iy, 1 + iy}Cy​=[iy,1+iy] parameterized by x↦x+iyx \mapsto x + iyx↦x+iy. Because of how f∘γf \circ \gammaf∘γ traverses ∂R\partial{R}∂R, it follows f(iy)f\p{iy}f(iy) and f(1+iy)f\p{1 + iy}f(1+iy) are on the sides of length 111 of RRR, and it follows that diam⁡f(Cγ)≥2\diam{f\p{C_\gamma}} \geq 2diamf(Cγ​)≥2. Thus,

diam⁡f(Cγ)=∫01∣f′(x+iy)∣ dx≥2.\diam{f\p{C_\gamma}} = \int_0^1 \abs{f'\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} \geq 2.diamf(Cγ​)=∫01​∣f′(x+iy)∣dx≥2.

On the other hand, by Cauchy-Schwarz,

∫01∫01∣f′(x+iy)∣ dx dy=∫Q∣f′(x+iy)∣ dA≤(∫Q∣f′(x+iy)∣2 dA)1/2(∫QdA)1/2=(∫Q∣f′(x+iy)∣2 dA)1/2(∫QdA)1/2.\begin{aligned} \int_0^1 \int_0^1 \abs{f'\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} &= \int_Q \abs{f'\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{A} \\ &\leq \p{\int_Q \abs{f'\p{x + iy}}^2 \,\diff{A}}^{1/2} \p{\int_Q \diff{A}}^{1/2} \\ &= \p{\int_Q \abs{f'\p{x + iy}}^2 \,\diff{A}}^{1/2} \p{\int_Q \diff{A}}^{1/2}. \end{aligned}∫01​∫01​∣f′(x+iy)∣dxdy​=∫Q​∣f′(x+iy)∣dA≤(∫Q​∣f′(x+iy)∣2dA)1/2(∫Q​dA)1/2=(∫Q​∣f′(x+iy)∣2dA)1/2(∫Q​dA)1/2.​

The Jacobian of f=u+ivf = u + ivf=u+iv as a function R2→R2\R^2 \to \R^2R2→R2 is given by

df=(uxuyvxvy).\diff{f} = \begin{pmatrix} u_x & u_y \\ v_x & v_y \end{pmatrix}.df=(ux​vx​​uy​vy​​).

Combined with the Cauchy-Riemann equations, this has determinant

uxvy−vxuy=(ux)2+(vx2)=∣∂f∂x∣2=∣f′∣2.u_xv_y - v_xu_y = \p{u_x}^2 + \p{v_x^2} = \abs{\pder{f}{x}}^2 = \abs{f'}^2.ux​vy​−vx​uy​=(ux​)2+(vx2​)=∣∣​∂x∂f​∣∣​2=∣f′∣2.

Thus, by the change of variables formula,

∫Q∣f′(x+iy)∣2 dA=∫f(Q) dA=area⁡R.\int_Q \abs{f'\p{x + iy}}^2 \,\diff{A} = \int_{f\p{Q}} \,\diff{A} = \area{R}.∫Q​∣f′(x+iy)∣2dA=∫f(Q)​dA=areaR.

Thus,

2≤∫01∫01∣f′(x+iy)∣ dx dy≤(area⁡R)1/2(area⁡Q)1/2=2,\begin{aligned} 2 &\leq \int_0^1 \int_0^1 \abs{f'\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} \\ &\leq \p{\area{R}}^{1/2} \p{\area{Q}}^{1/2} \\ &= \sqrt{2}, \end{aligned}2​≤∫01​∫01​∣f′(x+iy)∣dxdy≤(areaR)1/2(areaQ)1/2=2​,​

which is impossible. Thus, no such fff exists, which completes the proof.
